Day 25 - Sunrise's Event Creation

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Sunrise is a calendar app that acts as an intermediary between all of your other calendars. I started using it because it would pull my due dates from Trello, but I’ve also found that it integrates with just about every calendar service.

This is how you create an event in Sunrise, and some of the options available to you.

Why it’s good: Two words—consolidation and suggestion. First, every conceivable option that you can apply to this event is rolled into one densely packed interface. It is dense, but the flow makes complete sense because it feels like a list of questions, and that list matches how I think about my events:

  • What am I doing?
  • When?
  • Where?
  • Who?
  • Anything Else?

It rolls in smart suggestions, like having an incredibly fast and accurate calendar lookup, pulling in my address book for invitations, and even subtle things like changing the icon based on what the event is called.

My favorite piece of it though is that Sunrise allows you to create an event without asking you which calendar it’s on. This is incredibly important to an aggregation tool like this - I don’t want to think about how I have to create the event, I just want to create it. While the interface could be better, making the calendar the last choice before you save instead of the first choice (Like Outlook for instance) removes so much mental friction from the process, and allows me to focus on the more relevant details.

day 24 kinda sparkbox codepen case study what

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

Day 24 (Kinda): Sparkbox Codepen Case Study

What it is: A remarkably in depth, nuanced (formerly) real time case study.

Why it’s good: Really? Do you need an explanation of this? Let me finish hyperventilating and I’ll try.

First: Why do case studies exist? To get you work, right? This case study transcends that idea entirely. This will probably get Sparkbox work, but it is a tremendous gift to the design community. I’ve watched the process play out as they release new content, delighted by the nuance and watching them discuss about the places where the process works and where it doesn’t. The case study is specific to CodePen, and broad in thinking about how we design modern products. It is a real time, multimedia thesis.

Second: I guarantee that if you are a designer, you looked up Sparkbox and considered a move to the midwest after looking at this case study. It gives you such a powerful sense of who they are as a company, how they work, and what motivates them.

I don’t even know what else to say. Just… Go read it.

day 23 starbucks tipping what it is when you

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

Day 23: Starbucks Tipping

What it is: When you make a purchase at Starbucks with their app, it gives you the ability to tip your baristas for a few hours afterwards.

Why it’s good: When Starbucks first released the ability to pay with an app, I jumped at the opportunity. One less “loyalty” card to carry and a constantly refreshing bucket of coffee dollars. Tipping is really important to me, so I had a pretty constant annoyance that I would have to carry cash in to tip the baristas. What’s the point of a digital system if I still have to bring cash?

About a year ago, I gained the ability to apply a tip after a transaction happens, and the window stays open and adjustable for a few hours. The brilliance comes in a few forms, the preset amounts so it’s literally 1 tap to select an amount, the notification that indicates that the purchase has gone through (I don’t mind the prompt, it helps me to remember), and the transaction history that updates as you select the different amounts. The major selling point for me though is that it gives you the ability to select these amounts in the notification, which means I can give the baristas a dollar with my smartwatch.

Welcome to the future.

day 22 tumblr queue interface what it is on


Day 22: Tumblr Queue Interface

What it is: On the Queue page for Tumblr, it lists out the date and time that each post is scheduled for.

Why it’s good: For a project like this that aims at a single post a day, scheduling posts is a grand idea. The queue is an even better idea however, a list of posts that are automatically published every day at the same time.

I’m about to head off on a weekend trip, so I’ve been queuing up posts to hit for the days that I’m gone. How much do I have in the pipeline? Enough to get through the weekend?

These little tooltips next to each post answer my question immediately. Instead of having to count on my fingers or look at a calendar, I immediatelly know how much buffer I have built up and how long it will last. Perfect!

day 21 neutrogena face wash ingredients what it

100daysofgoodux100DaysProject

Day 21: Neutrogena Face Wash Ingredients

What it is: Neutrogena Naturals Face wash switches up how it handles the ingredients list, showing where the different elements come from.

Why it’s good: The average consumer has an odd relationship with the word “chemical.” We use the term as a stand in for a whole host of other bad terms; toxin, carcinogen, caustic, solvent, cleaner, the list goes on. Chemical names are just as scary, we don’t understand them so we assume it’s bad.

With the natural push in many products, manufacturers have an added difficulty of conveying what the ‘natural’ element of their product is. If I’m uninformed as a consumer, do I have any idea what “Cocamidopropyl Betaine” means? Definitely not, that sounds scary.

By listing where the ingredients come from, Neutrogena gives credibility to its claim. Instead of just seeing a lot of words that I don’t understand, I can see that it comes from a coconut. It’s a move that facilitates confidence, and helps me feel like they aren’t making baseless claims.
